July 8, 2012: Fiction
WICKED BUSINESS, by Janet Evanovich. (Bantam, $28.) The Salem, Mass., pastry
chef Lizzy Tucker and her partner, Diesel, take up a murdered Harvard professor’s
quest for a powerful ancient relic.
GONE GIRL, by Gillian Flynn. (Crown, $25.) A woman disappears on the day of her
fifth anniversary; is her husband a killer?
CALICO JOE, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $24.95.) A pitcher beans a promising
rookie, ending both their careers; years later, the pitcher’s son brings them together.
MISSION TO PARIS, by Alan Furst. (Random House, $27.) In Paris in 1938, an
actor stumbles into the clutches of Nazi conspirators who want to exploit his
celebrity.
CANADA, by Richard Ford. (Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers, $27.99.) A boy takes
refuge in Saskatchewan after his parents commit a robbery.
A DANCE WITH DRAGONS, by George R. R. Martin. (Bantam, $35.) After a
colossal battle, the Seven Kingdoms face new threats; Book 5 of "A Song of Ice and
Fire."
THE INNOCENT, by David Baldacci. (Grand Central, $27.99.) A hit man who has
become a target of the government rescues a teenage girl whose parents have
been murdered.
THE STORM, by Clive Cussler and Graham Brown. (Putnam, $27.95.) The 10th
NUMA Files novel.
THE THIRD GATE, by Lincoln Child. (Doubleday, $25.95.) Professor Jeremy Logan,
an “enigmalogist,” is called to Egypt to assist at a pharaoh’s newly discovered tomb.
PORCH LIGHTS, by Dorothea Benton Frank. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $25.99.) The
widow of a New York City firefighter returns to her Lowcountry South Carolina home.
STOLEN PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $27.95.) When a Minnesota family is
murdered, the Minneapolis investigator Lucas Davenport believes a Mexican drug
gang is involved.
11TH HOUR, by James Patterson and Maxine Paetro. (Little, Brown, $27.99.)
Detective Lindsay Boxer and the Women’s Murder Club investigate a possible serial
killer.
THE LONG EARTH, by Terry Pratchett and Stephen Baxter. (Harper/HarperCollins,
$25.99.) A scientist invents a device that allows travel to alternate Earths.
A BLAZE OF GLORY, by Jeff Shaara. (Ballantine, $28.) A re-creation of the Battle of
Shiloh in 1862.
July 8, 2012
Non-Fiction
THE AMATEUR, by Edward Klein. (Regnery, $27.95.) A journalist argues that
President Obama is callow and unable to lead.
COWARDS, by Glenn Beck and Kevin Balfe. (Threshold Editions/Mercury Radio
Arts, $28.) The radio host and founder of GBTV discusses 13 lies that politicians,
academics and the media perpetuate.
WILD, by Cheryl Strayed. (Knopf, $25.95.) A woman's account of a life-changing
1,100-mile hike along the Pacific Crest Trail.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner's
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
KILLING LINCOLN, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt, $28.) The host of "The
O'Reilly Factor" recounts the events surrounding the assassination of Abraham
Lincoln.
THE GREAT DESTROYER, by David Limbaugh. (Regnery, $29.95.) The talk show
host’s brother, a lawyer and columnist, describes the president's "war on the
Republic."
IT WORKED FOR ME, by Colin Powell with Tony Koltz. (Harper/HarperCollins,
$27.99.) Rules for effective leadership from the four-star general and former
secretary of state.
BARACK OBAMA, by David Maraniss. (Simon & Schuster, $32.5.) An account of the
president’s family background and coming-of-age shows the forces that shaped him.
UNINTENDED CONSEQUENCES, by Edward Conard. (Portfolio/Penguin Group,
$27.95.) A former managing director of Bain Capital argues that growing income
inequality shows the American economy is working.
AN AMERICAN SON, by Marco Rubio. (Sentinel, $26.95.) The Florida senator’s
memoir.
WHAT THE (BLEEP) JUST HAPPENED?, by Monica Crowley. (Broadside, $27.99.)
The Fox news analyst calls for a high-spirited conservative comeback.
STEVE JOBS, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of the
recently deceased entrepreneur.
I HATE EVERYONE . . . STARTING WITH ME, by Joan Rivers. (Berkley, $25.95.)
The comedian’s humorous reflections.
IMAGINE, by Jonah Lehrer. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26.) An account of the
science of creativity argues that it is not a gift but a thought process that can be
learned.
